title: Brexit news theresa may visit Gateshead eu uk
story: Brexit news: Theresa May and her Cabinet will be up North today (Image: REUTERS )The Brexit away-day will see the Mrs May attempt to woo workers at local businesses where she will promise to deliver a deal that &ldquoworks for every corner of the UK &ndash all the while grappling with continuing Cabinet tensions.A stinging YouGov poll in the Sunday Times showed little more than one-in-10 Britons thought her Brexit plan would be good for Britain and the same poll showed public support for Boris Johnson to take over as Prime Minsiter.Despite the poll blow Mrs May was to confirm a &pound780million investment in the East Coast Main Line, which services journeys between Doncaster, Leeds and Newcastle.She said: &ldquoMaking Britain a country that works for everyone, in urban and rural regions, is a priority for my Government and a thriving economy across the Northern Powerhouse is central to that.                Princess Diana fans ATTACK Camilla on her BIRTHDAY &ldquoWe have set out major policies and investments as part of our Modern Industrial Strategy to unlock the potential in the North and more than any government in history, we are making sure that we are delivering the outcomes that really matter to people who live and work here.The visit comes after&nbspBrexit Secretary Dominic Raab indicated he still needs to persuade some members of Mrs May's Cabinet to get behind the controversial Chequers deal.Mr Raab stressed he was &ldquofocussed relentlessly and unflinchingly on achieving a deal with the EU but the UK was serious about about the possibility of a no deal walkaway from the bloc.As London and Brussels squared down for an intensive 12 weeks of talks before the deadline for a deal in October, Mr Raab accused the EU of acting irresponsibly and trying to ramp up pressure on the UK with their projections of what the outcome of Britain crashing out of Brussels without an agreement would be.The ongoing Tory turmoil over Brexit comes as Mrs May was hoping to present the Cabinet's visit to the north east as a commitment to regional development post Brexit.The Cabinet meeting will see announcements of backing for technology and manufacturing development in the region.The move away from usual meetings in Downing Street will see a commitment to funding offshore and remote island wind to power millions of homes.Business and Energy Secretary Greg Clark is announcing on Monday that major projects in the region will receive a cash boost.After weeks of continued crisis over Brexit strategy, Mrs May will be hoping for a temporary breathing space as the Commons rises for the summer recess on Tuesday.She has ordered Cabinet ministers to use the break to go on a European charm offensive to sell her Brexit plans as she prepares to meet leaders of Estonia, Austria and the Czech Republic this week.

title: prince harry princess diana aids charity Sentebale Harry Amsterdam visit
story: Prince Harry is in Amsterdam to discuss his AIDs charity  (Image: KENSINGTON PALACE )The Duke of Sussex has joined advocates from his charity Sentebale using the opportunity provided by the Aids 2018 summit in Amsterdam to discuss issues faced by teenagers who have the disease.He said it was his aim to normalise the virus in a bid to encourage people to speak out.&nbspThe 33-year-old said: Those communities who have never had a HIV problem, need to start talking about it.&nbspFor the past few years,&nbsp&nbsphas been a committed HIVAids campaigner, raising awareness about the disease and even being publicly tested for the virus a number of times - once with superstar singer Rihanna in Barbados in 2016.                Tough day for May: PM launches Brexit plan in Gateshead                 Met Office tells Britons to stay indoors until FRIDAY as amber weat...Harry's charity Sentebale focuses on supporting HIV positive young people in the African nations of Lesotho and Botswana.The organisation's Let Youth Lead programme gives young people a public voice on the issue of AIDS and how if affects their lives, and during Monday some of the advocates will take part in a discussion with the duke.The programme hopes the testimony of the young people will be able to influence policymakers and after the debate they will hold a private meeting with those shaping the response of nations to the threat of HIV.The International Aids Conference is billed as the largest gathering on HIV and AIDS in the world, bringing together more than 15,000 scientists, activists, health providers, policy makers and global leaders.The conference is seen as an opportunity to strengthen policies and programmes that ensure an evidence-based response to the epidemic.Linda-Gail Bekker, president of the International AIDS Society and AIDS 2018 co-chair, said about&nbsp: His genuine commitment to the fight against AIDS is inspiring a whole new generation of leaders and reminding the world that AIDS is not over.We are so grateful to him for his leadership in the HIV response and the strong collaboration between Sentebale and the International AIDS Society.In the the evening&nbsp&nbspwill attend a British Embassy reception where he will meet leading young people from Holland.On Tuesday,&nbsp&nbspand Sir Elton John will share a platform as the celebrity - who performed at the duke's recent wedding - launches the MenStar Coalition, a global Aids organisation aimed at targeting HIV infections in men.

title: Brexit news UK Jacob Rees Mogg EU second referendum Theresa May latest
story: The chair of the pro-Brexit European Research Group (ERG) insisted Britain has already had three votes and warned that another vote to leave the European Union could result in never-ending Brexit referendums.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Westminster Hour: &ldquoWe&rsquove already had three votes. We had the vote in 2015 when David Cameron proposed a referendum, which people wanted. We then had the referendum itself.&ldquoWe then had a general election where both known parties said that they would respect the result of the referendum.&ldquoWe&rsquove had three votes already. The problem is, the people who want a second referendum are the Remainers who lost and they want the result reversed.Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg said the only people who want a second vote are Remainers who lost (Image: &bullBBC)&ldquoThey want it to be like Denmark and like Ireland and carry on voting until we do what the EU wants.&ldquoIf we vote to leave again, will they ask for a third vote and a fourth vote?He added: &ldquoI&rsquom all in favour of democracy and there will be a general election in 2022 and people will judge how the deal has been carried out by then.&ldquoBut the big decision has been taken. The big decision is to leave. How you leave is a subsidiary decision to that.&ldquoThat is a matter for ordinary political events and doesn&rsquot need a separate referendum.Prominent Tory backbencher Justine Greening made a desperate plea in July for a second referendum, claiming another vote is the only way to resolve the parliamentary stalemate.The former Education Secretary and Remain supporter, Ms Greening unexpectedly said the &ldquoleavers are right in opposing the Prime Minister&rsquos Soft Brexit plan.Writing for Times, the MP for Putney claimed the agreement is &ldquothe worst of both worlds.She wrote: &ldquoWe&rsquoll be dragging Remain voters out of the European Union for a deal that means still complying with many EU rules, but now with no say on shaping them.The Prime Minister gathered her cabinet together ahead of a crunch Brexit showdown at her country retreat at Chequers in Buckinghamshire                    PA1 of 14Members of the cabinet and government officials gather at Chequers&ldquoIt&rsquos not what they want, and on top of that when they hear that Leave voters are unhappy, they ask, &lsquoWhat&rsquos the point?&rsquo&ldquoFor Leavers, this deal simply does not deliver the proper break from the European Union that they wanted.Ms Greening said the &ldquoonly solution is to take the final Brexit decision &ldquoout of the hands of deadlocked politicians and give it to the British people.The Tory MP calls for Britons to be given three options on the ballot paper. Firstly, to accept Mrs May&rsquos Brexit proposal. Secondly, to leave on WTO terms. Or, thirdly, to stay remaining in the EU.Tory rebel Dominic Grieve also said on Sunday that a second Brexit referendum may soon be &ldquothe only solution.

title: 900 year old gold ring garden auction cornwall uk british museum
story: Now the British Museum has returned it to her following two years of analysis. And she is hoping to sell it.Deborah, 57, was working on fence posts in the back garden of her home in Crantock, Cornwall, when she made the discovery three years ago.The ring dates to around the 12th century and is valued at around &pound700.The mother of three said yesterday: I was hoping that the Royal Cornwall Museum in Truro might want to buy it as I would like it to stay locally. It is classed as a national treasure, but they said they were unable to buy it.                Letter reveals double grief of Jackie Kennedy                World's rarest collection of Star Wars action figures to sellI'd like it to stay in the county if someone was interested in it.When her children, now all adults, were small Deborah attended a night school studying archaeology and continued her interest for the past 20 years.She believes the significance of the ring could have been missed by someone with less historical interest.I picked it up and dusted it off and thought it looked like a child's ring as it was old and delicate. It looked like old gold and it wasn't tarnished, she said.The Antiques Roadshow made their first million pound discovery in 2008, here are their most valuable finds to date.                    BBC&bullTwitter1 of 20This Faberg&eacute flower brooch has reportedly been valued at up to &pound1 millionAt first Deborah put the ring on a dresser in her kitchen and forgot about it.But when she rediscovered it the following year she began the process of contacting museums, and an inquest was held into the treasure.Deborah said: I got in touch with the museum in Truro and then it was hand delivered to the British Museum.She added: I asked the previous landowners what the field had been used for, and was told it was a burial ground.The history of the village itself goes back to when a monastery was built. Generally back then, anyone from the church was wealthy. Crantock was also the main shipping area for merchants. There were probably a lot of wealthy people passing through.

title: UK weather forecast heatwave met office BBC weather latest forecast July 2018 this week
story: The entire nation is back on heatwave alert as health officials warn elderly, very young and vulnerable people to take extreme care.Thermometers are poised to rocket into the high 30Cs before next weekend putting the all-time UK record under threat.People with health conditions are urged to stay out of the sun as the country braces for the hottest blast of summer so far.The Met Office with Public Health England (PHE) has issued a level-2 heat health watch alert through the start of next week.Latest long-range outlooks show Britain locked in the oven for at least the next 10 days and possibly through to autumn.                Hosepipe ban 2018: Which areas have a hosepipe ban in place? the 30C (86F) mark.Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said the hot weather is being driven by high pressure over the UK and warm air flooding in from Europe.He said: &ldquoTowards the east and southeast it is going to be mostly fine, hot and sunny through next week with highs of 31C (87.8F) or 32C (89.6F) from Monday.&ldquoWe expect similar values on Tuesday but as we go through the week it is going to turn even hotter.&ldquoWe are likely to see temperatures of 33C (91.4F) or 34C (93.2F) by Wednesday or Thursday in the southeast and 35C (95F) is not out of the question.UK hot weather: overnight in parts of Britain bringing unbearable sleeping conditions, he added.He said: &ldquoSome places could see above 20C (68F) on Sunday night, this will be a difference to the last couple of nights when it has been a bit fresher.&ldquoHowever we are going to go back to a very warm and humid theme over the next few days.&ldquoNorthern England could see temperatures in the low-30Cs at the start of the week although it will be slightly fresher in Scotland.&ldquoHowever, even here we are looking at highs of 24C (75.2F) or 25C (25F) so it is still going to be much warmer than usual for the time of year.&ldquoThere may be the odd shower away from the southeast over the next few days and on Wednesday the heat across the south could trigger thunderstorms.The UK is about to roast in the hottest spell of the year so far as records for summer heat come under threat once again.The mercury is expected to rocket past the 33.0C (91.4F) highest temperature so far recorded in Porthmadog, Wales, last month.If thermometers nudge past 33C (91.4F) it will be the hottest day since last summer when London&rsquos Heathrow hit 34.5C (94.1F).If we beat the 34.5C (94.1F) on Wednesday it will be the hottest day since July 2015 when temperatures at Heathrow hit 36.7C (98.06F).With highs of 35C (95F) forecast by the end of next week Britain is facing some of the highest temperatures for a century.The record for July 25 is 33.9C (93.02F) set in Regent&rsquos Park, London, in 1900 for July 26 it is 33.3C (91.94F) recorded in Southampton, in 1885 and for the 27th it is 34.4C (93.92F) recorded in Margate, Kent, in 1933.The all-time UK record of 38.5C (101.3F) set in Faversham, Kent, in August 2003, could also topple before the end of summer, according to some long-range experts.There is also little chance of any significant rainfall over the coming weeks as Britain hurtles towards a drought crisis.James Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, said: &ldquoThis week will bring another period of very hot weather particularly across the south of the country where we could see temperatures approaching the mid 30Cs by the middle part of the week.&ldquoTemperatures will remain well above average elsewhere despite some occasional showers and some cloud cover in northern and western areas.Hot weather forecast: Europe will bask in hot weather this week (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoThis weather pattern is likely to stick around into August especially across the south and southeast where it is looking very warm though the forecast period.Relentless hot weather could set off explosive thunderstorms and hail showers over the next few days, he warned.He said: &ldquoAs always with this type of set-up and heat some developing thunderstorms could also become an issue towards the end of next week and into next weekend.&ldquoThese could also bring some notable and potentially noteworthy hail showers in their wake within this period.Government weather warnings for thunderstorms are likely to be issued before the end of the week, the Met Office said.Public Health England has warned the elderly, the very young and people with health conditions to take extra care as the heatwave rages on.Health protection consultant Dr Thomas Waite said: &ldquoTemperatures are likely to rise into next week which may leave older people, young children and those with long-term conditions, including heart and lung diseases, struggling to adapt to the heat.&ldquoSo keep an eye on friends and family who may be at risk.UK weather forecast shows a continental blast coming from Europe (Image: NETWEATHER)To beat the heat, try to keep out the sun from 11am to 3pm, walk in the shade if you can, apply sunscreen and wear a hat if you have to go out in the heat.&ldquoAlso try to carry water with you when travelling.The Met Office&rsquos long-range outlook predicts hot, dry weather will hold out through the start of August.It states: &ldquoIt seems most likely that the weather pattern will only change very slowly. Western and southern areas will often be dry, sunny and very warm, but with the risk of some cloudier periods with rain at times, or heavy showers and thunderstorms.&ldquoFurther north and east drier and more settled conditions are expected to be more dominant, although with the ongoing risk of heavy showers and thunderstorms breaking out at times.&ldquoTemperatures remaining widely above average for most, with further spells of very warm or hot conditions probable, and possible very hot conditions at times, especially in the southeast.Bookmaker Ladbrokes has slashed the odds on the hottest day of the year arriving before the end of this month.Spokeswoman Jessica Bridge said: &ldquoMother Nature's generosity with the sunshine is showing no signs of slowing down any time soon, and the odds suggest we could be on course for even more record-breaking temperatures.

title: Micheal Schumacher latest news Mallorca majorca home
story: German tabloid Bild said she had purchased the exclusive property on the upmarket estate of Las Brisas near Andratx in the southwest of the island so she could spend holidays there with her children and friends.The house was bought by building magnate Perez in 2005 but he put it up for sale last year after the death of his wife Mari Angeles Sandoval.The villa is part of a 15,000 square metre estate which boasts two swimming pools, a helipad, a gym and a huge palm-tree-fringed garden.Schumacher, the only driver in history to win seven F1 World Championships, was placed in a medically-induced coma after a life-threatening skiing accident in December 2013 in the French Alps.Michael Schumacher latest news: Wife Corinna has bought a mansion in Majorca (Image: •ABC)                Michael Schumacher news: Fury as YouTuber make 'tasteless' jokeHe was relocated to the family home on the shores of Lake Geneva in September 2014 where he continues to receive medical treatment and rehabilitation.Updates on his health have been few and far between.It has been reported he is looked after by a 15-strong medical team, with his care costing &pound115,000 per week.Majorcan papers have reported on the property deal, but have cited Bild as the source.Corinna bought the mansion for the family  (Image: )The May 2012 death from cancer of Florentino Perez&rsquos wife was said to be one of the reasons Florentino Perez might have decided to put the property up for sale when it emerged last year it was on the market.The couple used to be regular visitors to the house - called Villa Yasmin - but the Real Madrid president was rarely seen jetting to the island in the summer after she died.The gated estate it is built on is home to just a dozen houses and offers spectacular views of the Mediterranean from the Puig de Marmacen mountain.Michael Schumacher, the most successful racing driver in history.                    AFPGetty Images1 of 24Michael Schumacher is pictured at the Valencia Street Circuit in 2009Selina Scott, the former host of the BBC&rsquos first breakfast show, was said to have owned a home on the same estate around the time it was reported Florentino, 71, had put the 1990s-built property on the market.Upmarket real estate agency Engel&ampVolkers were said to be managing the sale.

title: ministers plan to stockpile processed food
story: Theresa May has ordered “no deal” planning “to step up” — with the government poised to start unveiling some of the 300 contingency measures in the coming weeks.At last week’s Chequers summit, Brexiteer ministers demanded more be done to prepare for Britain leaving the EU out without a new arrangement in place.The Sun can reveal that includes emergency measures to keep Britain’s massive food and drinks industry afloat - including stockpiling ahead of exit day on 29 March next year.More than £22 billion worth of processed food and drinks are imported in to the UK - 97 per cent from the EU - in an industry that keeps 400,000 workers employed in the UK.Similar stockpiles are also being prepared for medical supplies amid fears of chaos at British ports next year.Brexit department insiders also claim plans have also been “wargamed” to ease pressure on Calais, including importing and exporting more goods through Holland, Belgium and directly from Spain.Last night Downing Street said “no deal preparation work is to be stepped up” and led by new Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.Yesterday the Cabinet newbie briefed fellow ministers on measures Britain is taking, with No10 saying: “It’s sensible to make preparations for all scenarios and that includes No Deal.”With trade talks due to recommence in Brussels next week, a Whitehall source said: “preparations for no deal are actually much further down the line than people realise, and we will be making that clear in the coming weeks.”Meanwhile, Justice Secretary David Gauke warned Tory Eurosceptics that a “no-deal” Brexit was “not an attractive option at all”.While insisting that the option cannot be ruled out, Mr Gauke told the BBC: “What I would say to those of my colleagues, if there are some, who think this is pain-free and this is just something that we can ride over very easily, is no deal will have a negative impact on our constituents, on the British public.”But last night it emerged his department would be spending more than £17 million preparing for the scenario.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may should go home
story: They did so by a huge margin. Sadly, a year or so later they also voted to keep the appalling Anna Soubry as their local MP. Let’s hope they never make that mistake again.For the last year this bilious, jabbering woman has done everything she possibly can to thwart the will of her electors.She is a staunch Remainer and is seemingly prepared to bring down the Government to get her way. Her actions suggest she couldn’t give a monkey’s about what the people in her constituency think.Two nights ago she was one of 12 Conservative rebels who voted against the Government. She wanted Britain to remain part of a customs union with the EU. That would mean — effectively — no real Brexit. And if they had won, it would have been catastrophe for the Government. And in my opinion, the country.The reason they didn’t lose is solely down to a bunch of courageous Labour MPs, including the excellent Frank Field, who voted with the Government. Soubry isn’t alone, of course. The people of Loughborough, Leics, also voted by a large margin to leave the EU.But they are represented in the House of Commons by Nicky Morgan, who appears not to give a toss what they think. She also voted for a customs union. Nicky is famous among many for being the second worst Education Secretary this country has ever had. She’s pipped to the post for that particular prize by Justine Greening.Being useless in their Cabinet posts isn’t the only thing that unites these two women. Greening is also opposed to Brexit and she has even called for a second referendum. Because she didn’t like the result of the first one.The people of Beaconsfield, Bucks, voted to leave the EU. But their MP, the grim Dominic Grieve, who resembles a funeral director from about 1923, appears not to care less. He has said he’s prepared to “collapse” the Government if he does not get his way.Sarah Wollaston is another one. Another embittered MP. Her constituency, Totnes in Devon, voted to leave by a sizeable margin.Because while it is true that the majority of Labour MPs are also opposed to Brexit, they have been nothing like as dangerous as the Tory rebels.We are in a mess. The Prime Minister staggers from crisis to crisis, striking meaningless deals whenever she can to stave off defeat for a few more days.She surely cannot last much longer. A Remainer herself, of course, I think she should be persuaded to call it a day. Go home, put her feet up. And let her party elect a leader who will take no more c**p from Brussels.And no more c**p from the likes of Soubry and Greening, either.THE top scientist Richard Dawkins – Britain’s most famous atheist – has got himself into trouble.He has said that he prefers to hear the sound of cathedral bells to the muezzin wail calling Muslims to prayer.  Saying something as inoffensive as that is enough to get you into hot water these days.Dawkins has been called a bigot as a consequence. I have to say I disagree with him. I love the sound of cathedral bells, sure.But I also enjoying hearing the Muslim call to prayer – when I’ve been on my travels in Morocco or Malaysia. But, over here, it’s cathedral bells for me every time.Here’s a tip, then.Take them to an expensive shoe shop and make them look at the display through the window.And remember the noise they make.KATIE PRICE is on holiday in Thailand and of course she’s got her baps out.  This might be a problem for Katie, pictured with boyfriend Kris Boyson.Topless sunbathing is against the law over there. This is because tourists enjoy looking at the scenic islands. Without having their view obliterated by a pair of breasts the size of Koh Samui.So watch yourself, Katie. And as a break from lying on the beach, how do you fancy a spot of caving?YOU’VE got to love the toffs, haven’t you?  Most of them are absolutely crazy after years of inbreeding.Take the brilliant Lizzie Purbrick who described herself as “a very well-bred toff”.  She went round to her married lover’s home after he’d cheated on her with a third woman.No messing with Lizzie. She took with her eight litres of pig’s blood which she sprayed across his flat. She daubed the words “slut” and “whore” and “big d**k lord” on his walls and sprayed a giant penis on the floor.  She said: “So many people have said I should write my life story, but I’m so bonkers I can’t remember it.”The judge said – in one of the great under-statements of the decade – that she had “real concerns about the defendant’s ability to make rational decisions”.No s**t, Sherlock.It started out a few years back with just a couple of stalls. Now the entire town centre is closed off and thousands turn up to pig themselves on cuisine from scores of nationalities.I got so stuffed last year I needed to be helped home. And not a chicken parmo – the supposed Teesside dish of choice – in sight.IT’S not often that the Labour peer Dame Margaret Hodge says something worth repeating. But in telling her party leader Jeremy Corbyn that he was a “f***ing anti-Semite and a racist” I think she kinda hit the nail on the head.Meanwhile, the decent, moderate Labour MP John Woodcock has resigned the party whip and become an independent.Long-time party members – like I was, until last year – know that Labour is currently led by a hard-left anti-Jewish rabble of thickoes.I hope the voters twig this sooner or later.AND now it’s time for Hypocrites of the Week. A special award for Pimlico Plumbers of London.They’ve put up a giant banner outside their premises about Brexit, saying: “Nobody voted to be poorer!”Pimlico Plumbers has just lost a landmark case brought by one of its employees. He, like almost all of their staff, was kept on a contract which allowed the firm to pay him less than the proper rate.They were done under a UK Supreme Court decision, using laws designed to stop unscrupulous firms exploiting cheap labour.I wonder what it is about the EU that Pimlico Plumbers likes so much? Can you take a guess?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: sun says irish pm leo varadkar
story: It has exposed beyond doubt both his crass naivety and the cynical deceit of the EU masters he cravenly obeys.Imagine the cataclysmic self-harm of Ireland preventing planes from its biggest trading partner flying over it. And the impossibility of its own airlines avoiding UK airspace. It won’t happen.Varadkar must believe that these grenades he brainlessly lobs into the Brexit negotiations help Brussels. He is not bright enough to realise how absurd and unstatesmanlike he looks.But he let something else very revealing slip too.Varadkar reportedly said that EU leaders have assured him no hard border or customs checks will ever be needed between Ireland and Northern Ireland.That’s under ANY scenario, including a No Deal.Since we will never build a hard border either, why is “avoiding” one still being discussed, let alone a huge sticking point?Answer: It is a ruse, confected by a Brussels desperate to keep us in its grip.Eurocrats yesterday tore apart Theresa May’s Chequers offer. Yes, the same offer already so over-generous it almost collapsed her Government.The Sun has never been more gloomy about the chance of a deal. There is nothing more Mrs May can compromise on.But Brussels is run by deluded bullies who apparently think they cannot lose.Martin Selmayr, the German who is effectively in charge, dislikes Britain and insists any deal must be punitive.The EU, while apparently negotiating with us, is also advising its members how to lure away our job-creating firms.Parliament, and its Remainers, must not be cowed. They must back Britain over Brussels. No Deal wasn’t our choice. But the EU is pushing us into it and telling its members to be prepared.Within eight months we must be fully ready too, economically and politically.THE huge surge in serious crime shames the supposed party of law and order.It is no coincidence murders, rapes, robberies and knife attacks are soaring with police numbers at a 36-year low.For years the Tories considered their necessary cuts to budgets safe enough. The evidence against is now irrefutable.But more cash is not the only answer.Many forces are appallingly led, obsessed with their image, with social media virtue-signalling and investigations driven by political correctness, all while ignoring the basics of keeping the public and their property safe.Home Secretary Sajid Javid must secure more money and reverse this horrific trend.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: diana would have known how to fix the meghan and thomas markle debacle
story: So many people have ­commented on the likeness between the late Princess Diana and Charlotte, the granddaughter she sadly never met.Diana often spoke of her desire for a daughter and she would have doted on Princess Charlotte.I can imagine proud Granny taking her to Disneyland and buying Princess outfits. She would have let Charlotte run riot in her bedroom, trying on all her designer clothes and shoes and raiding her make-up bag.It’s so tragic that all of these happy times were not to be. When William saw all of his children come into the world, most especially baby Charlotte, he must have felt the loss of his mother even more keenly.Diana would have been there with her arms full of presents, and not just for the babies. There would have been thoughtful gifts for Kate and lots of hugs and happy tears.You can well picture her ­giving newlywed Harry a cheeky nudge and telling him to “get on with it” so she could have more grandchildren to spoil.I also think that if Diana had still been alive this sad situation between Meghan Markle and her dad would never have been allowed to turn so toxic.Diana would have seen this potential problem looming even before the engagement was announced and nipped it firmly in the bud.She would have insisted and ensured he was invited to the UK and would have dispensed shrewd and invaluable advice on how to deal with all of the hoopla surrounding the wedding. Diana learned the hard way how to deal with the media and palace officials. She was misquoted, manipulated and misunderstood during her time as a royal wife and knew all the pitfalls and how to avoid them.Skittish Meghan would have been soothed and calmed and all of the bad feeling among the Markle family would have surely evaporated.Diana would have advised Meghan’s dad on his wedding suit, helped him with his speech and rehearsed him walking down the aisle.She would have put this rather shy and ordinary man completely at ease.Rather than watching his daughter getting married on TV while cowering in a cheap bed and breakfast in the US, he would have been an integral part of the happiest day of her life.Instead, we have a constant stream of ill-advised interviews given by Thomas where he appears to have been ignored and abandoned and, whether it’s fair or not, Meghan seems increasingly cold-hearted.Photos yesterday of. him celebrating his 74th birthday alone with just a fast food takeaway for company don’t exactly help, whether they were staged again or not.A present, phone call or card from Meghan would have gone a long way to build bridges.It’s all turning a tawdry soap opera meaning commentators such as Sharon Osbourne will keep the pot boiling.Just this week she inferred Thomas has a drink problem and should get clean, ensuring more lurid headlines and bad feeling as he furiously has to deny all of the allegations.No one is coming out of this well and never has Princess Diana been more missed.Harry needs her wise counsel and William knows what an important part she could have played in the lives of his ­children.I know her sons will never really get over her death, but I do hope when William looks into his daughter’s beautiful eyes he is heartened to see a reflection of his mum rather than finding it ­unbearably sad.THE way BBC News treated Cliff Richard was utterly shameful and I’m not in the least surprised it lost its court case.The poor man went through years of hell and became a virtual recluse – and his physical and mental health was profoundly affected.At a time when he should have been enjoying the rewards of a lifetime’s graft, he was enduring sleepless nights and often crying in anguish on the kitchen floor.Many in the media have expressed fear and disquiet that any sort of Cliff’s Law will mean restrictions on newspapers, radio and TV, and this is indeed troubling.But the blame should be pointed firmly at those who thought it was a good idea to send a helicopter to film and report an OTT police raid on an innocent man.Seeing Cliff outside the courtroom this week looking extremely fragile and on the verge of tears was heartbreaking.Clearly the sunny, friendly, optimistic Peter Pan of Pop has gone for good and in his place is a haggard, careworn, wary victim.Before the court case, Cliff told me he doesn’t have photos taken with fans and their children any more.It was painful to see the hurt and mistrust in his eyes.He then revealed this week that his VIP status meant he was allowed to use the secret Wimbledon tunnel under Centre Court and Court No1 to bounce quickly between both venues and view as much tennis as possible.Cliff doesn’t do that any more, and never will, because the tunnel goes past the ball boys’ changing area and he doesn’t want to put himself in a situation where he could potentially be accused of something unspeakable.I really hope that when enough time has passed he can get some of that old “glass half full” spirit back, but he will never be the person he was.And no one else should have to go through such a hideous ordeal when they have done nothing wrong.IF you don’t want to watch a movie that will make you laugh, cry and come out singing Abba songs, we can’t be friends.I thoroughly enjoyed Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again – a rare example of a sequel that is better than the original.The starry cast includes Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, PIerce Brosnan, Andy Garcia and Colin Firth. But the cherry on the icing on the cheesecake is the legend that is Cher.I was lucky enough to host the world premiere this week in London and had the chance to talk to the cast, who were effusive in their praise of Her Cherness.It was surprising to hear she STILL gets nervous before going on set and she was genuinely bewildered by all the love in the air for her.I thought one elderly gay gentleman was going to explode with happiness when Cher blew him a kiss.It was so endearing – and there is nothing more deliciously camp than Cher stepping out of a helicopter in a blonde wig and sequins before going on to sing Super Trouper. She’s a class act and a throughly lovely woman.WATCHING politicians squabble like ferrets in a sack soon loses its novelty value – and our eyes are now glazing over whenever the dreaded subject of Brexit rears its ugly head.But we should never forget that when we woke up the day after the referendum – to discover a majority had voted to leave the EU – there was NO actual plan.Bupkis. Nada. Zilch. Diddly-squat.There wasn’t even a “to do” list.Instead, all the rats deserted the sinking ship, claiming the dog had eaten their homework or a big boy did it and ran away – leaving the (female) PM to tidy up their reeking mess. Funny that.No matter which way you voted, surely we can all agree on one thing.There was little or no thought put into how to actually implement such a seismic change. Not even a few notes on the back of a fag packet.Now, two years down the line, the whole big, fat mess is farcical and beyond parody.As a nation, we are a laughing stock.Shame on all those careerists and fence-sitters for their arrogance, stupidity and downright mendacity in not having even a half-arsed plan in place.A parcel of rogues, right enough.IF you fancy a right good laugh at some silly, bonkers, hilarious fun and games, tune in to BBC1 today at 5.05pm for another helping of Wedding Day Winners with myself and Rob Beckett.One couple will actually get married at the end of the show and it’s all very lighthearted and joyful.DID Burberry REALLY need to make a bonfire of its overpriced designer swag and burn an eye-watering £28million worth of clothing and cosmetics?In line with other designer labels, the fashion house claims the move was to stop counterfeiters getting their hands on garments and using them to produce fakes.But surely that just doesn’t add up.If criminals want to reproduce any designer clothes or handbags, they can go into any shop and purchase something – or, even simpler, just order it online.Could Burberry not instead have the mother of all sales in aid of Help for Heroes, or for the homeless charity Centrepoint, or any number of deserving causes here and in the Third World?That £28million would have gone a hell of a long way to help those in need.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady prime minister legacy
story: Because . . . ’twas ever thus — right? Politics is a man’s world and, to many, women still feel like token visitors.Even when Tony Blair famously had 101 “babes” in his 1997 intake of MPs, only four of his Cabinet appointments were female.Here we are, 20 years later, and yes, we have a female Prime Minister but there is still a prevailing view that the Cabinet, in particular, belongs to men.Clearly there’s something profoundly wrong with that equation.Given that this country is made up, more or less equally, of men and women, things would undoubtedly be fairer, not to mention calmer, if more women were on board.So the big question is, why aren’t there?Things are better than they were. Since the 2017 election there are 208 women in the Commons, up from 191 in 2015.But there are still not enough and you don’t have to look far for reasons why that might be.Most women are put off by the environment and the culture and wonder why on earth they would want to put themselves within a country mile of either.Take Prime Minister’s Question Time, which appears to be a bunch of overgrown public school boys booing, jeering and jostling with each other in their bid to establish who is top dog.What woman in her right mind would choose to enter that fray?Then there are the practicalities. This week, Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson was “cheated” in a crunch Brexit vote by the breaking of her pairing pact.This is an arrangement where one MP agrees not to vote to cancel out the fact that another MP on the opposite side is unable to vote — in this case Swinson was at home with her three-week-old baby.The problem was, her pairing partner reneged on the deal and voted.Then there are the hours, which can be difficult if you have a family. Any woman would need a very understanding partner and family to do the job.Also, any MP is opening themselves up to the line of fire and a lot of personal criticism — which multiplies for female MPs.Some have to deal with endless comments and speculation about their appearance, as well as threats of rape and death on a regular basis. Just this week a man was arrested over abusive Facebook posts aimed at various female MPs.If it’s true voters are biased against women, any female has to be ten times as talented, determined and tenacious to get the job in the first place.It’s no wonder women are put off entering politics.But if we want true equality then more women need to go into Westminster and the culture needs to change.That is why I support the campaign group Women To Win and will be taking part in an event called The Voice Of Women In Politics.The idea is to try to encourage more women into Parliament, outlining some of the changes that need to take place to raise the number of female candidates.Getting more women into politics is a no brainer.Women tend to work collaboratively to solve problems whereas — in my experience — men are more likely to lock horns, point fingers and try to shout the loudest. All too often men are interested in progressing to be a leader, whereas women are more focused on getting the job done.And when women DO find their voice in politics, it can be very powerful, and they often hae the balls to say things that men just wouldn’t.Look at Tory minister Anna Soubry, who this week suggested the PM should take control of her hardliner MPs and stop pandering to the likes of Jacob Rees-Mogg.I know she’s got a lot on her plate at the moment, but if I was Theresa May I would be spending a good proportion of my time and energy on making real changes to politics in order, specifically, to attract many more women.It could be one of the greatest legacies she could hope for.Thomas Markle is a concerned dad who just wants to be reconnected with his daughter.Meanwhile this HALF-sister has turned a constant shade of green and wants to get involved in any way she can.Is it any wonder she wasn’t invited to the wedding?MY heroine of the week is 21-year-old Emilia Holden a waitress in Georgia, US, who was at the end of a shift when a customer casually grabbed her bottom as he walked past.Her response? She followed him, grabbed him and body slammed him to the ground, then called the police – after which he spent two nights in a police cell.What a fantastic response. Good for her.But also, who are these men that think that they can just grab a woman’s behind just because they want to?But hearing about elaborate plans by Pixie Lott which include a total of 18 bridesmaids all wearing the same dress, left me feeling a bit stressed out.Apart from anything else, it will take them all an hour to travel up the aisle.JAMES GODDARD-WATTS, the businessman whose family founded the hardware firm Screwfix, is still locked in a multi-million pound divorce battle with his ex-wife, Julia.They reached an agreement eight years ago ­– following the end of a 13-year marriage – that Mrs Goddard-Watts should get a £3.25million house and a £4million lump sum.But she complained that Mr Goddard-Watts had not revealed the full extent of his wealth at the time of the settlement and court fights began.Critics say Julia is a leech, greedy and after his money.But when you consider the worth and value of building a home, looking after children and a family while supporting a spouse, that should be worth at least half of whatever the partner who didn’t do all of that has earned in the meantime.So why shouldn’t she take him back to court?The law states that assets are divided equally.So people who hide theirs from their spouse only have themselves to blame if said spouse feels forced to take them to court to get what’s fair.ELLE Macpherson’s diet regime is enough to make me reach for the pizza delivery menu.The model is up at 5am. She has warm water, lemon and cayenne pepper.She has no booze, almost no carbs, no meat and no dairy. She is such a follower of the alkaline diet – based on the theory you can change the pH of your body through food – that she checks the acidity of her urine.I’m sure the diet is good for her – but who wants to add years to your life if those years are going to be so, well, dull?“The only chance I have of being on TV again is if I were very ugly,” he said.“I think only old, ugly women can get on TV. Like Mary Beard.”David added that he would only be hired now: “If I had tombstone teeth and rather funny hair and made a lot of noise about that fact.”Oh dear.Where even to start? When you resort to attacking someone’s appearance, you are in trouble.It’s not Mary Beard that has held back his career. It’s David himself.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: ayesha hazarika clusterfudge pm dishcloth leadership
story: The Tories are so busy plotting against each other they have forgotten there is a country to run.They have become a circular firing squad. Or a crap remake of Fight Club — except they DO talk about Fight Club. All the time.Theresa May has the leadership skills of a damp dishcloth, no authority and no political vision.A strong leader needs a clear mission. You may not agree with it, but you know what they stand for.“Live each day like it’s your last,” is our Prime Minister’s political strategy, except she’s not dancing in the rain.She is waiting for the sharks to circle. And soon they will come for her.Buffoon-in-chief Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg — a man so old-fashioned he could have been dug up by Time Team — wait to pounce. And Brexit is a mess. Things are so bad, even Elon Musk is out of ideas. No one will be happy with where we end up.And because there is no party political or Brexit majority in the Commons, politics is stuck, trapped in what feels like a never-ending Brexistential crisis.Normally, I’m with “Brenda From Bristol” when it comes to more elections and referendums.But maybe a People’s Vote on the final deal or another election is the only way to unblock Brexit.Think of it like a political plunger — unpleasant, nasty but necessary.You’d think the Opposition would be gleefully capitalising on all this chaos. Think again. Instead of going after the Tories, Labour has decided to traumatise the Jewish community. Again.Labour has had a horrible problem with anti-Semitism, yet instead of healing the wound, it has poured vinegar on it by choosing not to adopt the full International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance code of conduct.These guys sound pretty authoritative and the code is good enough for government departments and the Crown Prosecution Service.Many Jewish groups and leaders, including the Chief Rabbi, are distraught, confused and angry. And you can see why.This shameful decision led to an angry clash outside the Commons chamber where Jewish MP Margaret Hodge confronted Jeremy Corbyn, allegedly calling him an anti-Semite and a racist.Hodge lost family in the Holocaust and fought off the BNP in her Barking and Dagenham constituency.Instead of acknowledging her pain and offering to sit down with her, Team Corbyn are taking disciplinary action against her.I bet they deal with her far quicker than they did with Ken Livingstone, who couldn’t stop banging on about Hitler.What dark times for Labour, which once had a proud tradition of fighting racism. They must sort it out.Then we have the Lib Dems, who have proved useless. They have one policy — stop Brexit.Yet leader Vince Cable and ex-leader Tim Farron missed crucial votes on Monday. Talk about Dem and Dumber.To top it all off, the DUP’s Ian Paisley Jnr has been suspended for 30 days — which hasn’t happened since 1949 — for failing to declare lavish holidays to that well-known Northern Irish stakeholder, Sri Lanka.And to think Theresa May planned to give MPs an extra five days off as a reward for all their hard work.The country has had enough of these fools’ infighting, incompetence and filling their boots. Especially when we face so many big problems, from NHS funding to housing.Parliament’s end-of-term report is a big, fat fail. British politics should be taken into special measures.THE premiere of Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again was sun-kissed, frothy fun –  and no one mentioned the ­Customs Union. Bliss.The stars were out in full, including Cher. She is magnificent, but it is a little odd that at 72 she has fewer wrinkles than any other cast member, including 29-year-old Lily James. And the baby.She told Lorraine Kelly it was down to not drinking, smoking or doing drugs. Yeah, right.We women may be naive when it comes to the quest for eternal beauty, but we ain’t stupid.WHEN you hear of people getting up in the middle of the night and queuing, you think of the Boxing Day sales or the release of the latest Apple gadget.You don’t think of childcare.Yet more than 100 parents queued from 3am – armed with chairs, flasks and biscuits – trying to bag their child a coveted place in the breakfast club at a primary school in Cardiff.For many working parents, breakfast clubs are a lifeline.They can drop off the children in a safe environment where they can get a decent breakfast, then make it to work on time themselves.Though parents have the right to request flexible working hours, many fear the sack if they come in late.These spaces were limited and dished out on a first-come, first-served basis, which is why the parents took such drastic measures.This shows how desperate parents are for childcare that matches their working hours.The scrapping of Labour’s extended school programme and the first real-terms cuts to schools mean all these extras that were provided are no longer affordable.Childcare isn’t a luxury.It’s a necessity for millions of families and they are crying out for more breakfast and after-school clubs.JEFF BEZOS, the boss of Amazon, is a man clearly in his “Prime”.He’s now the richest man in modern history.Good for him.I’m all for celebrating entrepreneurs and hard work – but shouldn’t that apply to his poor workers toiling away in his warehouses?They would probably give Amazon working conditions zero stars.I wish our business leaders remembered some of their forefathers, who felt a moral and civic responsibility to look after their employees and took some pride in that.It makes business sense too. Happy workers are better workers.So after Bezos pops open the champagne, maybe he could spare a thought for his staff, who told an undercover reporter they pee in bottles because the loos are too far away and they are afraid of being accused of time-wasting.C’mon, Jeff – that’s really taking the p**s. ONE school in Liverpool had to apologise after kids as young as four were left in tears when they were denied an ice cream treat because they didn’t have a 97 per cent attendance record.How mean is that? What if they were ill? And surely it’s the parents’ fault.CARERS got another kick in the teeth this week when the Court of Appeal overturned a decision that those doing sleep-in shifts should earn at least the minimum wage.If the decision had gone through, it would have cost the UK care sector billions – so charities and local governments were relieved.But it shows what a raw deal carers get.Judges said only hours spent awake counted as work – but that is completely out of touch with the reality of what carers do.Many of the elderly and vulnerable people they look after need their help through the night, whether it’s a trip to the loo, to take medication or dealing with more serious situations such as seizures. Carers can’t exactly fall into a deep sleep. They have to be alert and listening in case they are needed.The rooms they sleep in may not be comfortable and they will be away from their own families.Many carers are paid so little that they live hand to mouth and barely get by.When I met a group in the West Midlands, they told me they couldn’t afford to put the heating on in winter and had to take their kids to the grandparents’ for tea once or twice a week just so they would be fed.Some were struggling so much they had to visit food banks.But they also loved their jobs and took great pride in looking after their clients as if they were family.They get paid a pittance, with some earning just £30 for a ten-hour shift.These low-paid workers – the majority of whom are women – are unsung heroes and deserve more.New Health Secretary Matt Hancock must make social care a priority and enforce minimum-wage law properly.It’s time we took better care of our carers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david beckhams broke nephew says hes been frozen out of the family while brooklyn and romeo live the high life
story: Freddie Every, 17, grew up playing with his cousins Romeo and Brooklyn but now lives in temporary housing with his hard-up dad.The footie-mad teen feels he was cast adrift when his dad Colin, 50, and Becks’ eldest sister Lynne split up after 11 years of marriage in 2010.Freddie is now on a bricklaying course while living with his dad in a one-bedroom council flat in Dagenham, East London, reports the Sunday Mirror.He is desperately trying to reach out to the Beckhams and is dying to be reunited with his extended family.Freddie told the newspaper: “I just want to be able to go for a meal and talk and catch up. I’m not asking for more than that. They are still my family and I’d like to see them again.“Growing up we saw them loads and I have so many happy memories of playing at their house, doing Easter egg hunts and playing on quad bikes.“Then suddenly it all stopped and I am on the outside looking in, only seeing them live their lives on Instagram or on the TV.”The teen has been reminiscing about the time he played with Becks and Cruz at Rowneybury House in Hertfordshire.He also remembers the time David bought him a McDonald’s Happy Meal when he was a kid.And despite growing up with Brooklyn, their lives could not be more different as Freddie has just £1.36 in his bank.Freddie’s first job was at Romford Market, where he worked on a noodle stall earning £200 a month.Brooklyn, however, recently took home £100,000 for a photo shoot he did for phone company Huawei.He is forced to ride a mountain bike because he can’t afford driving lessons while his famous cousin drives a £35,000 Land Rover.Freddie last saw Becks, 43, nine years at a Chinese restaurant in Harlow, Essex, and in 2012 he went for a meal at Pizza Express with his cousins and Victoria, 44.

title: united utilities hosepipe ban shareholders pay
story: Despite being under fire for limiting water usage to 7m homes in the north west of England as its reservoirs run dry, the firm will dish out its largest payout in a decade.The company has blamed the lack of rainfall for its dry reservoirs despite being the only firm in England and Wales to impose a hosepipe ban.But it was recently revealed to lose more than 400 million litres of water every day from leaks, and has turned to sniffer dogs to detect pipe faults.Meanwhile, United Utilities boss Steve Mogford earned £2.3m in 2017.Jim McMahon, the Labour MP for Oldham West and Royton, said: “This isn’t just about water leaking out but money which should be used to maintain the water network leaking out as quickly.The first and last responsibility of the water company should be about maintaining the supply, and it has failed.”A spokesman for water regulation authority, Ofwat, said: The decisions some water companies have made on dividends, financial structures and top executive pay have damaged customer trust.Through measures we announced earlier this month, we are strengthening the incentive on companies to improve their performance for customers and cutting the rewards that come from financial engineering.United Utilities was fined £8m for under-performance last year. It said the payouts were in line with retail price inflation and its five-year growth policy.A spokesman said: “We deliver a range of benefits and long-term value for customers, the environment, and shareholders.Between 2015 and 2020 , we are investing over £3.5bn in essential infrastructure.”Thames Water last month announced it would halt bonuses to bosses this year and suspend dividend payments to its shareholders.The ban means customers will not be allowed to use either a hosepipe or sprinkler to water their gardens.They were also told not to fill up paddling pools, or face fines of up to £1,000.A statement added: Please use a watering can instead or, even better, reuse any water from the home such as water from washing up bowls or bath water.We know hosepipe bans can be inconvenient but by taking these steps now we can make sure we have enough water for more essential things like drinking, washing and cooking.The North West is the second region facing a hosepipe ban after Northern Ireland.

title: newborn baby left hot car tesco newton abbott devon car park
story: The disturbing footage sparked fury online after an eyewitness heard the baby crying in a supermarket car park.The car was spotted in the car park of Tesco in Newton Abbot on Thursday, when temperatures reached around 26 degrees.A man recording the cries is heard to say the baby is screaming its head off and that it was outrageous and out of order.According to a report on Devon Live supermarket staff issued an urgent shop broadcast when they were informed of the baby in the car by a member of the public.A Tesco spokesman said: A customer told one of our colleagues that a young child had been left on their own in a parked car at our Newton Abbot store.We put out a call in store for the vehicle’s driver, and they returned to their car.Commenting on the incident on social media, one person confirmed it was the grandfather who had left the baby in the car and the parents were now aware of it.Writing online, some said it was horrendous and  disgusting.Meanwhile, the British Red Cross issued a warning urging everyone to take care in the soaring temperatures last month.

title: cosplay anime kawaii hyper japan
story: We pass a killer whale sitting on a stone and a wounded Japanese warrior wiping blood off his Samurai sword.A panther slinks by as twirling princesses twist magic lamps above their crystal-encrusted veils. They pause and gawk at my blue bob, fruity tutu and 7in platforms.It may sound like the set of a fantasy film but I am in fact just one of the 80,000 wig-wearing guests at Hyper Japan Festival in London to celebrate Cosplay — costume role play — and Japanese culture.Youngsters from across the UK are dressed as their favourite characters from anime — a type of animation featuring futuristic heroes in action-led stories — as well as from cartoons, video games and comic books. Even the odd US comic supervillain is wandering round.All have been warned to not wear outfits smaller than a swimsuit as it is a “family event”.One of the first to greet me is Efe Aighorr, 28, a digital director from Canada Water, South East London, who has more than 45,000 followers on Instagram.He is dressed as Golden Jaguar from Marvel’s Black Panther. He says: “I’ve been doing it for two-and-a-half years and love it. I have a serious job so it’s great to morph into a different person and have fun.”But it was not known as Cosplay until 1983, when it was used by film director Nobuyuki Takahashi in Japanese magazine My Anime.The doll-like Kawaii style is common here among young British girls — and is the one I have opted for.As Princess Fairy Kei, I have blue hair, fake eyelashes, pink eyeshadow and am in a pastel dress adorned with cartoon ice creams.Another popular choice is Lolita fashion, a street style inspired by Victorian dolls. Fans include pop stars Gwen Stefani, Katy Perry and Nicki Minaj.All this does not come cheap. I meet impeccably dressed Sade Kaye, 20, a student, from Stratford, East London, who has “blown” £10,000 on her neon-heavy Harajuku street style, which originates from the Tokyo district it is named after.She says: “It’s an expensive addiction. I used to spend £1,000 a month on clothes. At the time I was working in a call centre and taking home around £1,500 a month.“I live at home so saw it as disposable income but just wasted it on outfits. I buy some I don’t even need.”She adds: “I once had an interview at a stationery shop. They were gobsmacked when I rocked up in silver space boots, a mini skirt and crop top.”A job is not the only thing she struggled to get. Sade’s look is stopping her from getting a boyfriend too, as “a lot of guys look and think I’m crazy”. But she admits she would “rather have amazing clothes”.She is in the right place. An entire floor is devoted to exhibitors hawking schoolgirl outfits, maid uniforms and other cute dresses, along with wigs, accessories and make-up. There are also craft shops where designers teach new Cosplayers how to make their own outfits.I run into London street performer Matt Johnson, 35, who is dressed as a Japanese warrior, and later Tabitha Hastie, 27, a software developer from Canada Water.Her outfit, inspired by Mercy from the Overwatch video game, cost £200. She has another which cost £500. She says: “I dread to think how much I’ve spent. But I love the whole experience and feeling part of a community, so it is worth it.”60% are aged between 23 and 3940% of Cosplayers are male£300 the amount most would spend on a costume It is easy to forget that away from Hyper Japan, these are all normal people with normal jobs.Laura Johnston, 26, is a civil servant. But today she is Morrigan, from computer game Dragon Age.She says: “I wear office attire to work but as soon as I’m home I dress only in Cosplay. My fiance doesn’t understand it. He doesn’t know it yet but I’m going to take weapons to our wedding.”Cosplaying for confidence and escapism are common themes.Emma Langley Soryu, 27, a warehouse worker from Birmingham, is dressed as Asuka, from Nineties’ Japanese TV series Neon Genesis Evangelion. She tells me how she is quite shy but “gets to be a different person in my costume”.With the compliments and selfie requests rolling in for me as I walk round, it is easy to see why Cosplaying is so addictive.Saya Elyn, 29, an accountant who has flown from Belgium to be here, says: “It makes me feel special. I like creating costumes and being someone else, as my job is so boring.“It’s a great way to make new friends. Everyone is so supportive and guys really like it, too. I even Crossplay, which means I dress as a man and become one of them.”Upstairs, a fashion show is beginning. A long queue of Cosplayers and Kawaii girls wait backstage, keen to show off their over-the-top costumes.Essex student Shannon Gallagher, 22, Harriet Day, 22, a pharmacy assistant, and Jade Mogford, 23, a waitress, are turning heads in their Arabian princess outfits. Each have tailored theirs to match their favourite anime.Shannon says: “We love dressing up and have hundreds of amazing outfits. We are getting stopped for a lot of pictures today, it’s great people love our outfits so much.”Like others I have spoken to, the three girls are single — a common theme. Perhaps it is because the scene can be hard to understand as an outsider.Kawaii girl Jess Redman, a single 24-year-old customer service worker from Bristol, says: “Sometimes people love it and say you look great and other times people look terrified and run away.”Yet there is a more sinister side to Cosplay. A 15-year-old female guest tells me: “People think they can touch you and lift up your skirt. It can be scary if you’re by yourself.“They see Lolita as a sexual thing but that’s because some people try to turn it into a fetish. Those people aren’t welcome in the community.”But not all the youngsters I spoke to had a problem with Lolita being perceived as sexual.Emma Barnes, 20, a student, started adopting the style when she was 12, as it “made me feel confident and sexy”.She adds: “I was an outcast in school, no one looked at me. But when I’m in my cute Kawaii costume I feel like a million dollars.”I can vouch for the fact that getting all dressed up makes you feel special, but after eight hours my feet are killing me, I am sweating under my wig and my body is aching under the heavy outfit.Now, where are my Primark PJs?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: divers swim 20 shaks cornwall coast
story: The 20-strong pack were snapped off the coast of Penzance, and were thought to have been attracted by the warm weather.Charles Hood, who runs Blue Sharks Cornwall, took the stunning picture while offering customers the “ultimate shark adventure in Cornish waters”.He told Cornwall Live: “There have always been blue sharks in Cornish waters but they’ve definitely increased in the past couple of years.We normally see ten when we go out, five on a poor day but around 20 on a good day.I would say there’s usually double the amount around that you see.”Charles runs shark-spotting trips from Penzance - and his jaunts have proved a hit with celebrities.He claims that BBC presenter Steve Backshall once took one his tours - which have been featured on The One Show and Countryfile.He added: The blues can appear within minutes or up to a couple hours but once around the RIB they will often stay for a few hours at a time.Encounters are best photographed either using a pole-cam or snorkelling.”In April we told how a seven-metre basking shark stalked a kayaker off Porthcurno, Cornwall.And last week swimmers were ordered to stay out of the water after a massive shark lurked just inches from a harbour in Cornwall.The 9ft-long predator was filmed close to the shore in the popular Cornish holiday town of St Ives.

title: sir john major steps up calls for second eu referendum saying another vote is morally justified
story: He predicted Britain will “crash out without a deal” because hardline Brexiteers would refuse to back Theresa May’s soft Brexit plans.He said a second referendum would be “morally justified” because the “people who have least are going to be hurt most”.His call for a another vote directly contradicts his comments before the June 2016 referendum, when he said a second vote wouldn’t be “politically credible” adding: “If we vote to stay out, then we are out and we will have to get on with it.”But yesterday Europhiles jumped on his rallying cry - with senior Tory rebel Dominic Grieve telling Sky News that a second referendum “may be the only solution”.In an interview on the Andrew Marr Show yesterday Sir John sneered at Brexit voters by saying the “pie in the sky” arguments in favour of leaving were as credible as believing the “earth is flat”.Asked if he backed a second referendum, Sir John said: “It has downsides. I mean, frankly, a second vote has democratic downsides. It has difficulties.“But is it morally justified? I think it is.“If you look back at the Leave campaign a great many of the promises they made were fantasy promises. We now know they are not going to be met.“A referendum isn’t an easy option, but it’s not one at this stage that I would rule out.”Meanwhile Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab hit out at Remainers claiming that Vote Leave cheated by breaching spending limits in the referendum.He said their criticism was “last-ditch tactics by some to try and stop Brexit from happening”.Mr Raab added: “Discrediting the referendum, calling for second referendums, I don’t think that helps at all.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may to sell soft brexit plans to northern england
story: The PM will then talk to workers at local businesses - promising to deliver a Brexit deal that “works for every corner of the UK”.To mark her first Cabinet meeting in the North East she will confirm a £780 million investment in the East Coast Main Line to boost the number of seats and shorten journeys between Doncaster, Leeds and Newcastle.Last night the PM said: “Making Britain a country that works for everyone, in urban and rural regions, is a priority for my Government - and a thriving economy across the Northern Powerhouse is central to that.“We have set out major policies and investments as part of our Modern Industrial Strategy to unlock the potential in the North - and more than any government in history, we are making sure that we are delivering the outcomes that really matter to people who live and work here.”Mrs May has also ordered her Cabinet ministers to use the summer break to go on a European charm offensive to sell her Chequers Brexit plans.This week Mrs May will meet the leaders of Austria, Estonia and the Czech Republic.Her deputy David Lidington will travel to France, while Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt will fly to Berlin today to meet his counterpart for the first time since replacing Boris Johnson.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: He denied he was planning to set up a new centrist party but added: “I do like the idea of working with other people who have a common approach to politics.”The Lib Dem leader missed last week’s crunch vote on the Customs Bill, which the Government won by just three votes.Yesterday it was revealed he was at a dinner party that discussed the creation of a new centrist party.He insisted any “realignment” would involve other figures joining the Lib Dems - or joining in a coalition to fight Brexit.Sir Vince told the BBC: “I was having a confidential private discussion. I do talk to people in other parties - it’s part of the job.“The immediate preoccupation is to work with people in other parties to stop Brexit - that’s the priority.“But in the longer term there may be realignment because of the deep splits in the parties and I want my party to be in the centre of it.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: amazon brexit civil unrest doug gurr no deal
story: The internet giant was accused of peak Project Fear after its top exec in the UK made the prediction and claimed he was engaged in emergency planning for the scenario.Doug Gurr, head of Amazon in the UK, made the startling claim in a meeting of around 40 business representatives with Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab on Friday, according to The Times.His warning stunned other guests at the meeting - with some reported to have expressed scepticism about the drastic prediction.Mr Gurr said it was part of his worst-case scenario contingency planning for a No Deal Brexit.But Tory MPs have hit out at the prediction and claimed it was part of the campaign to keep Britain closely tied to the EU.They also mocked the firms reputation for minimising its tax bills by cleverly exploiting global rules.Marcus Fysh tweeted: Time to make @AmazonUK contribute to rather than asset strip the UK retail environment.Simon Clarke added: This may be Peak Project Fear? Always dangerous to call it, of course, because there are always new heights of nonsense to be scaled.And Robert Halfon joked: More likely to be civil unrest when Amazon delivery drones drop packages in wrong garden/or front drive.An Amazon spokesman refused to confirm or deny the remarks were aired at the meeting on Friday.A spokesman said: Like any business, we consider a wide range of scenarios in planning discussions so that were prepared to continue serving customers and small businesses who count on Amazon, even if those scenarios are very unlikely.This is not specific to any one issue - its the way we plan for any number of issues around the world. Mr Raabs spokesman did not respond to a request for comment last night.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle sister samantha dad thomas cbb hint
story: Samantha said she and Thomas Markle had offered Meghan an “olive branch” - as she appeared to confirm that she will appear on Celebrity Big Brother.Speaking during an interview on Good Morning Britain – Samantha said the family are “surprised and disappointed” with Meghan for not contacting her father.She said: “It is important for them to reunite. It is important for everyone - for our family, for the world.Thomas Markle did not attend his daughters wedding on May 19 because he claimed he needed major surgery after suffering a heart attack.His health issues came amid claims the relationship between Meghan and her family had been further strained after the fallout over paparazzi shots Thomas had staged for cash.Samantha was reminded of a comment she made recently in which shed said that if her father died, Meghan would be responsible.Asked whether she regretted the remark, she said:  To a degree, but now it is so critical. My father is 74 now - life is short.It is so unfair. If there is a misunderstanding then she (Meghan) should reach out to him and clarify that to him.Samanthas comments came days after it was reported Meghan and Thomas could be reunited  in the US within months.Meghan is allegedly planning a solo trip to America without Prince Harry to visit friends and family in her native country.A source told Us Weekly: Shes planning a personal, unofficial trip this summer to see family and friends.In addition to begging Meghan to reach out to her father, Samantha also appeared to confirm she will be on Celebrity Big Brother.She claimed it was not disparaging or harmful to enter the CBB house and speak about her half sister.She has been heavily rumoured to appear on the Channel 5 show and has hinted that shed like to be as famous as the Duchess of Sussex.Speaking via link from Virginia, US, Samantha told Charlotte Hawkins and Kate Garraway: I’ve worked in media most of my life why would I not? Why would I stop living because we have a family issue going on?Asked what Meghan would make of her possible appearance on the reality show, Samantha added: I think she’s intelligent enough to be able to separate the two. Whether you’re a celebrity or a royal you have a high profile which is subjected to scrutiny from the media.I dont see how we are any different. No one has a copyright on our life experiences. I think the public forgets that we are individuals with our own life experiences. No disrespect but it’s not just Meg. If we can share that with the public thats great. Its not disparaging or harmful.Samantha then reacted angrily when asked whether she was cashing in on her sisters status.She said: For someone to say you should turn down a pay check - go tell your boss you don’t want a pay check for interviewing me as thats cashing in.After being asked outright whether she will be appearing on this summers CBB, there was a lengthy pause before Samantha finally blurted: I would tell you but then I would have to kill you, she joked. I dont want to find myself in locks and stocks - quite frankly it wouldn’t be becoming.Furious GMB viewers took to Twitter to blast the show for giving Samantha more TV airtime.One viewer wrote: This markle woman is full of venom about her now royal sister.. Stop the car crash tv and humiliation she wants to dish out, and let her climb back under her stoneA Kensington Palace spokeswoman said: This is not something we would comment on.

title: a quarter of brits would back a far right political party because they think the mainstream has let them down
story: As Theresa Mays Chequers deal continues to anger Brexiteers, growing numbers of people are set to back extreme parties.More voters are feeling alienated from the two main political parties, the polling showed.24 per cent would be prepared to support a group which harboured anti-immigrant and anti-Islam policies.And in findings that sent a warning shot to No10, the YouGov survey found 38 per cent would vote for a new party on the right that was committed to Brexit.Meanwhile, one in three voters said they would support a new anti-Brexit centrist party that could overturn the referendum result.The findings could show the UK is following the rest of Europe in seeing a rise of far-right parties.The after effects of a migrant crisis and scepticism after the Brexit vote have seen voters veer towards the right.Donald Trumps former chief strategist Steve Bannon said last weekend he wanted to capture this across Europe to boost the spread of far-right groups.And former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson has found a new following of supporters after he was jailed for 13 months for breaching court reporting restrictions around a trial.But the rise of Jeremy Corbyns far-left Labour party, who are still riding high in Britains polls, and Spains socialist party taking over the Government, have shown voters are more divided than ever.The YouGov survey for the Sunday Times also revealed Boris Johnson has more than twice the support of her to deliver on Brexit.Some 34 per cent said the former Foreign Secretary would be best placed to oversee the Brexit talks with Brussels and lead the Tories into the next election.This compared to just 16 per cent for Mrs May.Just one in nine voters support her plan, and just 12 per cent think it would be good for Britain.fMost voters dont think it stays true to the referendum result either.And a separate poll of Tory members for the ConservativeHome website found two in three Tory members oppose her Chequers plan.The findings will heap even more pressure on Mrs May to change tack and change the Chequers plan she agreed just over two weeks ago - which has been torn apart by Brexiteers.

title: manchester hilton hotel deansgate woman throat slit latest
story: The victim managed to flag down cops at around 11.10am today with lacerations to her neck after she was attacked at the Hilton Hotel in Deansgate.The woman has now been taken to hospital with serious injuries while armed police continue to sweep the hotel.Cops confirmed three men and two women have been arrested on suspicion of attempted murder.Dramatic pictures show two women being led away from the scene by cops - including one in the back of a police van wearing her pyjamas.A huge cordon is currently in place outside the hotel and in one of the rooms as police investigate.A horrified witness said his colleague saw the victim lying injured on the floor.Anthony Hilton told MEN: We saw a police van turn up in the carpark.One by one they starting arriving, there must have been at least 15.One of my colleagues was walking back. He saw a woman on the floor with a large slash across the throat.Police were with her at that point, more and more police turned up. They were running in and out of the Hilton Hotel.Then an ambulance turned up and they have only just taken her away.Another witness said the woman ran out of the hotel screaming and holding her throat.Greater Manchester Police said the incident is not believed to be terror-related.A spokesperson added: Armed police are currently at the Hilton Hotel on Deansgate after a woman was attacked inside the hotel.Shortly after 11.10am on Monday 23 July 2018 police officers on Deansgate were flagged down by a woman with serious injuries to her neck.The woman is being treated for lacerations to her neck.Three men and two women have been arrested on suspicion of attempted murder.
